ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Gained familiarity with extremely valuable overview of the history of sinological methods and their connections with broader philosophical approaches to language and meaning.

This course offers me a thorough exploration of the early encounter between China and other cultures through the lens of language study. Unlike the traditional sinology or philology, this course guides me to a critical reflection on their legacy, examining the historical and epistemological foundation of the biased mutual recognition and considering the potential inspiration to the transcultural studies nowadays.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Could include a wider variety of shorter readings, also more direct contrast of opposing perspectives.

The readings were all well-picked and the discussion usually inspired me a lot. However, in very few cases, the discussion digressed to a very specific sub-field that some of our classmates may have less knowledge about.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Only to another student who is greatly interested in these themes.
Yes. The course overall is a rigorous intellectual challenge that all graduate students interested in Chinese culture or transcultural studies would enjoy.
